claim: The working hours of Americans have increased over time.

supporting.text: Historical data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics shows that average weekly working hours for full-time employees in the U.S. have increased since the mid-20th century.

attacks.text: Historical data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics shows that average weekly working hours for full-time employees in the U.S. have increased since the mid-20th century.
The data does not account for the rise of part-time employment, which has grown significantly and may offset the increase in full-time working hours.
Even with part-time employment growth, full-time workers still constitute the majority of the workforce, so the overall trend of increasing hours remains valid.
Technological advancements have led to more efficient work, meaning longer hours may not necessarily equate to more productive work.
Despite efficiency gains, studies show that many industries have maintained or increased workload expectations, keeping hours high.

supporting.text: The rise of the gig economy and freelance work has led to many Americans working longer hours to supplement their income.

attacks.text: The rise of the gig economy and freelance work has led to many Americans working longer hours to supplement their income.
Gig economy jobs often offer flexibility, allowing workers to choose their hours, which may not necessarily lead to longer working hours overall.
Many gig workers take on multiple jobs out of necessity, leading to longer cumulative working hours despite the flexibility of individual gigs.
Official labor statistics often undercount gig workers, making it difficult to accurately measure changes in working hours.
Recent studies have improved methodologies to include gig workers, showing a measurable increase in working hours for this segment.

supporting.text: Technological advancements, such as smartphones and remote work tools, have blurred the boundaries between work and personal time, leading to longer working hours.

attacks.text: Technological advancements, such as smartphones and remote work tools, have blurred the boundaries between work and personal time, leading to longer working hours.
Studies show that while technology enables constant connectivity, it also allows for flexible scheduling, which can reduce total working hours by enabling efficient time management.
Flexible scheduling often leads to work encroaching on personal time, as employees feel pressured to respond to work communications outside traditional hours.
Many companies have implemented policies to limit after-hours communication, reducing the impact of technology on extending working hours.
Enforcement of such policies is often weak, and employees may still feel implicit pressure to remain available beyond official working hours.

supporting.text: Economic pressures, including stagnant wages and rising costs of living, have forced many Americans to work more hours to maintain their standard of living.

attacks.text: Economic pressures, including stagnant wages and rising costs of living, have forced many Americans to work more hours to maintain their standard of living.
Technological advancements and automation have reduced the need for long working hours in many industries, counteracting economic pressures.
Despite automation, many jobs still require human labor, and economic pressures dominate in sectors resistant to automation.
Government policies and labor laws have increasingly promoted work-life balance, limiting the increase in working hours.
Enforcement of labor laws is inconsistent, and many workers lack protections, allowing employers to demand longer hours.

supporting.text: Studies indicate that salaried employees in the U.S. often work beyond their contracted hours without additional compensation, contributing to an overall increase in working hours.

attacks.text: Studies indicate that salaried employees in the U.S. often work beyond their contracted hours without additional compensation, contributing to an overall increase in working hours.
Many salaried employees have flexible schedules and can offset extra hours with time off, meaning total working hours may not actually increase.
Flexible schedules are not universally available, and many employees still face pressure to work extra hours without compensation.
Official labor statistics show that average weekly working hours in the U.S. have remained stable or slightly decreased over the past few decades.
Official statistics may not fully capture unpaid overtime and off-the-clock work, which are common among salaried employees.

supporting.text: The decline of union representation in the U.S. workforce has reduced protections for workers, leading to longer hours without proportional increases in pay or benefits.

attacks.text: The decline of union representation in the U.S. workforce has reduced protections for workers, leading to longer hours without proportional increases in pay or benefits.
Many industries have adopted automation and flexible work arrangements, reducing the need for longer hours despite union decline.
Automation and flexible arrangements are not universally adopted, and many workers still face pressure to work longer hours due to job insecurity.
Global competition and economic pressures, not just union decline, are the primary drivers of longer working hours.
Union decline weakens collective bargaining power, making workers more vulnerable to economic pressures that drive longer hours.
